Graphical abstract The utilization of Pt-based catalysts in the catalytic conversion of propane to propylene (PDH) remains pivotal in industrial processes. However, the scarcity of Pt and its high cost necessitates innovative strategies to enhance Pt dispersion and catalytic performance. In this study, we present an approach involving the in-situ incorporation of Zn cations into Silicalite-1 (S-1) zeolite through one-pot hydrothermal synthesis, which facilitates the anchoring of atomically dispersed Pt atoms. The synthesized 0.5Pt/Zn@S-1 catalyst exhibits the dehydrogenation performance of 25 % propane for approximately 34.2 % propane conversion and 95.1 % propylene selectivity (propylene turnover rate of 14.2 s−1), coupled with robust stability of up to 60 h without distinct deactivation under a WHSV of 49.1 h−1. Comprehensive characterizations reveal the formation of atomically dispersed Pt-Zn catalytic sites. The Pt atoms are incorporated with the Zn cations and dense silanol nests. This unique configuration facilitates a synergistic effect between Pt and Zn for dehydrogenation. Keywords Propane Propylene Dehydrogenation Platinum Zinc Deactivation Sintering Zeolite Synergistic effect Silanol nest Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The significance of propylene in industrial production is undeniable, as it serves as a crucial building block for various industrial intermediates that are essential raw materials used in diverse manufacturing processes.[1–5] Compared with traditional steam cracking and fluid catalytic cracking processes, direct dehydrogenation of propane (PDH) shows great advantages in raw material cost and propylene selectivity. Especially, with the increase of available shale gas resources in recent years, the purposeful production of propylene through propane has attracted more and more attention.[1–5] So far, Pt-based catalysts are still widely applied in the industrialized Oleflex process.[6,7] However, the scarcity and high cost of Pt metal usually necessitate a high dispersion with a large exposed metal area for easy accessibility of reactants. Hence, developing a Pt-based catalyst for PDH with high dispersion and good catalytic performance is needed. Strategies for improving the performance of noble-metal catalysts have been widely explored.[7–14] Precious metals with high dispersion on the support surface may easily aggregate into large particles or be poisoned by coke deposition.[15–18] The strong electronic interaction between noble metals and low-cost metals (e.g., Sn, Zn, Ga, Fe, etc.) results in a synergistic effect in bimetallic catalysts, which enhances the performance of the PDH reaction and improves the sintering resistance of highly dispersed active sites.[19–28] Due to the abundance of Zn reserves on Earth, it has become increasingly common to use it as an additive to disperse Pt sites. Zn, as a common ingredient in Pt catalysts, effectively controls the activity and selectivity in PDH reactions. Whether used as a promoter or support (e.g., ZnO), the presence of Zn has been shown to enhance the catalytic performance of Pt-catalysts in the chemoselective dehydrogenation of propane to produce propylene. Zn is a more electropositive metal that is conducive to the formation of bimetallic Pt-Zn and/or Pt-ZnOX entities,[29–31] which favor the desorption of C = C bonds, thus improving the propylene selectivity. In addition, many studies have shown that the PtZn bimetallic clusters or nanoparticles can be well anchored by defective sites inside the pores of siliceous zeolites, forming a robust metal-support structure as active sites,[21,29,32–35] which can effectively inhibit the deactivation of the active sites induced by sintering and carbon deposition. As mentioned above, incorporating Zn into Silicalite-1 (S-1) zeolite can give rise to increased catalytic performance in PDH reactions.[36] Therefore, it is worthwhile considering the effects of Zn species with distinct chemical states on stabilizing the Pt sites atomically. Herein, this work reports an approach involving the in-situ incorporation of Zn cations into Silicalite-1 (S-1) zeolite through one-pot hydrothermal synthesis, which facilitates the anchoring of atomically dispersed Pt atoms. The Zn cations were first incorporated into the S-1 zeolite to obtain Zn@S-1 by one-pot hydrothermal synthesis. Then, Pt was impregnated on Zn-modified S-1 zeolite (Zn@S-1) to produce the 0.5Pt/Zn@S-1 catalyst. The protocol is shown in Scheme 1 . The 0.5Pt/Zn@S-1 catalyst exhibits outstanding catalytic performance compared with that of 0.5Pt/2.0Zn/S-1 (this catalyst was prepared by a conventional two-step impregnation method) under the same condition. Comprehensive characterizations are applied to investigate the activity-structure correlation of the 0.5Pt/Zn@S-1 catalyst. It is revealed that the Zn cations (Znδ+) can assist in immobilizing the Pt0 active sites via the formation of a positively charged atomically dispersed bimetallic Pt0-Znδ+ structure. Moreover, the enhanced catalytic activity of 0.5Pt/Zn@S-1 is attributed to the atomically dispersed bimetallic Pt0-Znδ+ sites anchored by the dense silanol nests of the S-1 zeolite surface. This unique configuration facilitates a synergistic effect between Pt and Zn species, significantly enhancing the catalyst's performance. This work brings new insights into the design of high-performance Pt-based catalysts. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation All chemicals were used as received. The modified Zn-zeolite (Zn@S-1) was synthesized by a “one-pot” hydrothermal method. In a typical synthesis, 10.0 g of tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, AR, SiO2 ≥ 28.4 %, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.) was introduced into the mixture of 21.45 g H2O together with 11.71 g of tetrapropylammonium hydroxide (TPAOH, 25 wt% in water, Energy Chemical Co., Ltd.) by syringe pump at the rate of 100 μL/min. The mixture was stirred in an ice-water bath for 1 h and heated to 70 °C for 3 h. Then 12.0 g of isopropanol (IPA, AR, ≥ 99.7 %, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.) was added dropwise at a rate of 500 uL/min and stirred for 20 min. The molar composition of the gel was 1 SiO2: 4 IPA: 0.3 TPAOH: 35 H2O. Finally, 2.69 g of 0.32 M [Zn(NH2CH2CH2NH2)3](OAc)2 aqueous solution was added dropwise at a rate of 100 uL/min and stirred for 30 min. The precursor solution was then transferred to an oven at 170 °C for 4 days. After repeated washing and drying, the powers were calcined in air at 550 °C for 6 h with a heating rate of 1 °C/min. Notably, the primitive S-1 zeolite is synthesized based on the above scheme but lacks the final step of adding Zn. The actual content of Zn in the Zn@S-1 and 2.0Zn/S-1 zeolites was determined by ICP-OES ( Table S3 ). As a comparison, the 2.0Zn/S-1 catalyst was obtained by post-synthesis of the incipient-wetness impregnation method. The Pt-modified Zn@S-1 or 2.0Zn/S-1 zeolites were prepared by the incipient-wetness impregnation method. A water solution of Pt(NH3)4(NO3)2 (Pt, 50 % basis, Sigma-Aldrich) was added dropwise to the prepared zeolites. After constant stirring, the mixture was leftat room temperature for 2 h. Finally, the mixture was roasted at 353 K overnight to remove water. After grinding, it was put into a muffle furnace calcined in static air at 500 °C for 4 h with a heating rate of 3 °C/min. The content of Pt in the final catalyst was nominally fixed at 0.5 wt%. The preparation method of the 0.5Pt/S-1 catalyst is the same as above. 2.2 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were applied to characterize the crystalline structure of the fresh and used catalysts on an Ultimate III diffractometer (Rigaku, Japan) at the range of 5° < 2θ < 80°. TEM images and HAADF-STEM images were recorded by FEI Talos F200S G2 microscope at 200 kV (FEI, USA). Simultaneously, the chemical components were conducted on an FEI Super-X energy-dispersive spectrum (EDS) system with a collection solid angle above 0.45 rad. The Pt dispersion was studied by CO pulse chemisorption (CO-Pulse) via a BELCAT-B analyzer (MicrotracBEL, Japan). Before the experiment, 50 mg of each sample was pre-treated using 100 mL/min H2 at 500 °C for 1 h. The actual elemental contents of the catalysts were determined by an iCAP 7000 series inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES, Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA). The physical properties of catalysts were studied on an ASAP 2020 plus (Micromeritics, USA). Before the test, the sample was vacuumed at 200 °C for 8 h. The BJH method and t-plot method were used to calculate the mesoporous and microporous specific surface area and volume of the catalyst, respectively. The data of FT-IR spectrum and Py-IR spectra were recorded on a Thermo-Fisher iS100 FT-IR spectrometer (USA). 29Si solid magic angle NMR (29Si MAS NMR) experiment was carried out on a 600 MHz NMR spectrometer (JEOL ECZ600R, Japan). The Shimadzu UV-2400PC instrument was applied to collect UV–Vis spectra equipped with BaSO4 for comparison. H2-TPR was carried out on an AutoChem II 2920 chemisorption analyzer (Micromeritics, USA) with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Before the test, 200 mg of the fresh catalyst was pretreated under flowing Ar at 400 °C for 0.5 h. The temperature was heated from 100 °C to 800 °C with a ramping rate of 10 °C min−1 under a flow of 10 % H2/Ar (30 mL/min). NH3-TPD profile of the catalyst was conducted on a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 chemisorption analyzer with a TCD detector. The test procedure was that 100 mg of the sample was pretreated in flowing He at 400 °C for 1 h, and then the NH3 adsorption was carried out at 40 °C for 0.5 h in 10 % NH3/He (30 mL min−1), followed by converting the flowing gas to He to remove the physical adsorption on the surface until the baseline kept stable. The NH3-TPD profile was recorded at a ramping rate of 10 °C min−1 from 100 °C to 600 °C. For the C3H6-TPD, 100 mg of the fresh catalyst was pretreated under a flow of 10 % H2/Ar (30 mL min−1) at 550 °C for 2 h. The flow gas was switched to He after the pre-reduction was complete, and cooled to 40 °C. Then, the catalyst was exposed to 5 % C3H6/Ar mixture gas for 1 h until adsorption saturation, followed by purging with He for 2 h at 100 °C to remove physical adsorption on the surface. Finally, the TPD profiles were recorded from 100 °C to 600 °C at a ramping rate of 10 °C min−1. Pt L3-edge and Zn K-edge X-ray absorption spectra in fluorescence mode were collected on BL-11B and BL-14 W1 beamlines of the Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility (China). The spectra of Pt foil and Zn foil were recorded as the references. The catalyst pellets were prepared for testing under environmental conditions. According to the standard protocol, the collected XAS data was processed and analyzed by the Demeter software package[37] and using the HAMA Fortran software package for generating WT EXAFS patterns from ESRF (Morlet function, kappa = 10, sigma = 1).[38,39] The surface chemical property of the catalysts was analyzed by XPS on a Thermo Scientific ESCALAB 250 (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA) equipped with a monochromatized Al Kα X-ray source (200 W). The binding energies were referenced to the Si 2p peak at 103.5 eV. DRIFTS-CO adsorption experiments were conducted on a Nicolet iS50 FTIR spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA). The experimental process was as follows: the sample was loaded into an in-situ cell (Harrick Scientific Instrument, USA), and purged by a flow of Ar (>99.99 %, 30 mL/min) at 300 °C for 0.5 h. Then the background spectrum was collected after the sample temperature was dropped to room temperature. In the end, the 10 % CO/Ar mixture gas was fed into the cell with a flow rate of 20 mL/min, followed by purging with Ar and beginning to record the DRIFTS-CO spectra. The thermogravimetric analysis (TG) of the spent catalyst was investigated using TG-DSC on a STA449F5 Jupiter thermal analyzer (Netzsch, Germany). The temperature was raised from 30 °C to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min in air (30 mL/min). Raman spectroscopic measurements were performed on a DXRxi Raman microscope (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA) with the excitation wavelength of 532 nm, and the wavenumbers were recorded from 400 to 3000 cm−1 with an average of 30 scans. 2.3 Catalytic activity tests The dehydrogenation of propane was carried out on a fixed-bed tubular quartz reactor at 0.1 MPa. Typically, 100 mg of catalyst was diluted with 500 mg quartz sand (40–60 mesh) and then loaded into the reaction tube with an inner diameter of 6 mm. Prior to each test, the catalyst was pre-reduced with 20 mL/min 5 % H2/Ar at 550 °C for 2 h. After that, the reactive gas of 5 % C3H8 balanced with Ar (50 mL/min) was fed into the reactor for the catalytic performance test. The propane conversion ( X C 3 H 8 ), propylene selectivity ( S C 3 H 6 ), the yield of propylene ( Y C 3 H 6 ), specific activity, carbon balance (CB), deactivation constant (kd) [33,40], and weight hour space velocity (WHSV) are calculated as the following equations: (1) C a r b o n B a l a n c e % = ( 1 / 3 [ C H 4 ] o u t + 2 / 3 [ C 2 H 6 ] o u t + 2 / 3 [ C 2 H 4 ] o u t + [ C 3 H 8 ] o u t + [ C 3 H 6 ] o u t ) / [ C 3 H 8 ] i n × 100 % (2) X C 3 H 8 % = ( [ C 3 H 8 ] i n - [ C 3 H 8 ] o u t ) / [ C 3 H 8 ] i n × 100 % (3) S C 3 H 6 % = [ C 3 H 6 ] o u t / ( [ C 3 H 8 ] i n - [ C 3 H 8 ] o u t ) × 100 % (4) S p e c i f i c a c t i v i t y s - 1 = N u m b e r o f p r o d u c e d C 3 H 6 m o l e s p e r s e c o n d N u m b e r o f t h e w h o l e o f P t m o l e s = F C 3 H 8 × Y × M w m c a t . × W P t × 22.414 L / m o l (5) C 3 H 6 t u r n o v e r r a t e s - 1 = m o l e s o f p r o d u c e d C 3 H 6 p e r s e c o n d m o l e s o f t h e s u r f a c e P t a t o m = F C 3 H 8 × Y × M w m c a t . × W P t × P t d i s p e r s i o n × 22.414 L / m o l (6) D e a c t i v a t e c o n s t a n t k d ( h - 1 ) = [ ln 100 - X e n d X e n d - ln 100 - X i n X i n ] / T i m e (7) W H S V = mass of propane mass of catalyst × t i m e Where F represents the flow rate of hydrocarbon (L/min), Y is the yield of propylene and mcat. is the weight of catalysts (g). The mass transfer limitation is analyzed in Note S1. Under the catalytic evaluation, the measured activity is not limited by external or internal mass transfer. In addition, 25 % or pure propane gas was used in the PDH test with high propane concentration and deactivation test. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The propane dehydrogenation (PDH) catalytic performance and deactivation study Two kinds of zeolites, surface Zn-modified Zn@S-1 and Zn/S-1 were synthesized by “one pot” synthesis and incipient wetness impregnation, respectively.[13] Subsequently, the same amount of Pt was loaded for further investigation. Two catalysts, 0.5Pt/Zn@S-1 and 0.5Pt/2.0Zn/S-1 were obtained and evaluated for the catalytic performance in the same PDH reaction. The catalytic performance was tested using 5 % C3H8/Ar as reactant gas without adding H2 (Fig. 1 ). The propane conversion of 0.5Pt/Zn@S-1 catalyst remained at ∼ 69.8 % after 40 h (Fig. 1 A). The theoretical equilibrium conversion calculated by Aspen is ∼ 73.4 % at 550 °C ( Fig. S1 ), while the measured initial conversion of propane is ∼ 71.8 %, this result illustrates that the synthesis method playing a critical role in maximizing exposure of its active sites. As the control experiment with the same usage of Pt, the initial propane conversion of 0.5Pt/2.0Zn/S-1 catalyst is ∼ 53.4 % and decreased to 26.6 % after 40 h of reaction (Fig. 1 B), which indicates that the catalytic active sites changed significantly during the reaction. The long-term stability under realistic and harsher reactions is a crucial factor in assessing the catalyst merit. The optimal catalyst is tested at a relatively harsh reactant gas concentration of 25 % propane. It is gratifying that the catalytic stability of up to 60 h without distinct deactivation (Fig. 2 A), testifies to the robust structure of active sites for 0.5Pt/Zn@S-1. Furthermore, considering that all the PDH catalysts eventually deactivate, the deactivation of the designed catalyst was accelerated by harsh reaction condition. The deactivation was carried out under the reaction condition of pure propane gas with a WHSV of 94.2 h−1 at 550 °C. The high WHSV is adopted to control the propane conversion below the thermodynamic equilibrium ( Fig. S1 ). As shown in Fig. S6 , the propane conversion of 0.5Pt/Zn@S-1 catalyst decreased from 26.2 % to 14.6 % with the selectivity toward propylene of 96.5 % after 28 h of reaction. Notably, the remarkable propylene turnover rate [41] of 14.2 s−1 and accumulative turnover numbers of 988,341 per surface Pt site for 28 h of reaction (Fig. 2 B and Fig. S7 ). The comparison of the reported catalyst activity shown in Table S2 fully reflect its catalytic activity and catalytic stability. However, the regeneration results of the catalyst suggest it cannot be restored after 2nd regeneration ( Fig. S6 ). The corresponding analysis for the permanent deactivation of this catalyst is due to the severe sintering of active metals during the regeneration protocol, as detailed discussed in Note S1. Moreover, the best-performance 0.5Pt/Zn@S-1 catalyst is superior to that of most Pt-based catalysts reported in the literature.[29,30,42–49] Compared with the very low propane conversion of monometallic 0.5Pt/S-1 and/or Zn@S-1 ( Fig. S3 ), the bimetallic PtZn catalyst exhibits enough excellent PDH performance. Therefore, it is necessary to investigate the structure of the PtZn sites, and further unveil the structure feature of 0.5Pt/Zn@S-1 distinct from 0.5Pt/2.0Zn/S-1. 3.2 Micro-structure characterization of the 0.5Pt/Zn@S-1 catalyst The XRD patterns ( Fig. S12 ) show that all the synthesized samples are the typical MFI structure.[50] The maintained peaks at 7.9°, 8.8°, 23.1°, 23.8°, and 24.3° of the Zn@S-1 zeolite indicate that the addition of Zn in the synthesis process does not change the MFI structure. No diffraction signals of Pt or Zn species are distinguished in these fresh samples, suggesting that Pt/Zn particles are highly dispersed or the size of crystal grains is difficult to detect. Therefore, TEM was carried out to further observe the morphology of metal particles. As shown in the bright-field TEM (BF-TEM) and dark-field TEM (DF-TEM) (Fig. 3 and Fig. S13 ), there are no visible particles existing in the fresh 0.5Pt/Zn@S-1. Combined with EDS and line scan, it is indicated that the Pt and Zn species are uniformly distributed in the inner surface of zeolite pores. In addition, the actual metal loading of the catalysts was determined based on ICP-OES shown in Table S3 . The loading of Pt is similar with around 0.3 ∼ 0.4 wt%, while the loading of Zn in the spent catalysts decreases, which is attributed to the loss of weak bounded Zn under the reaction conditions.[51,52]. The structure properties of zeolite pores over the prepared 0.5Pt/2.0Zn/S-1 and 0.5Pt/Zn@S-1 catalysts were analyzed via nitrogen adsorption–desorption. The adsorption branches of both catalysts are type II (Fig. 4 A) patterns, typical for microporous materials. However, the N2 uptake of 0.5Pt/2.0Zn/S-1 catalyst is higher than that of 0.5Pt/Zn@S-1 catalyst, which indicates that different synthesis methods will affect the pore structure. The pore size distribution in Fig. 4 B shows that the pore structures of the two catalysts are slightly different, the amounts of micropores on the 0.5Pt/Zn@S-1 catalyst is more than that of 0.5Pt/2.0Zn/S-1 catalyst. However, the micro-mesoporous surface area and pore volume of 0.5Pt/2.0Zn/S-1 catalyst is larger than those of 0.5Pt/Zn@S-1 catalyst (Table 1 ). Therefore, this result shows that the reason for the high dispersion of 0.5Pt/Zn@S-1 catalyst is not due to physical properties, but owning to Zn modification in different local positions in zeolite. 3.3 The incorporation of Zn and Pt into the zeolite in the 0.5Pt/Zn@S-1 catalyst The interaction between the silanol groups and metal species was studied by the FTIR spectrum. The FTIR spectra of the primitive S-1 zeolite exhibit two major absorption peaks at 3722 and 3500 cm−1 (Fig. 5 A), the one at 3722 cm−1 corresponds to external isolated silanol groups.[29,53] The other band at 3500 cm−1 is associated with hydrogen-bonded silanol groups, i.e., silanol nests or defect sites.[32] In the case of Zn@S-1, the peak intensity of the silanol nests is found to decline compared with pristine S-1. When Pt is further introduced, the intensity of the overall hydroxyl groups decreases slightly. According to the previous report, the major silanol nests are located in the pores of zeolites, while the isolated silanol group is located on the external surface.[54,55] Therefore, it can be speculated that Zn species are predominantly trapped by silanol nests in the pores of Zn@S-1. In addition, the metal-support interactions of the prepared catalysts were further demonstrated by 29Si MAS NMR (Fig. 5 B and Table S4 ). The resonance at −103.0 ppm is assigned to the framework Si-OH groups (Si(OSi)3(OH), Q3),[32,56] the other bands at −113.2 and −115.4 ppm are attributed to framework Si(SiO)4 species (Q4).[32,56] The decreasing intensity of the band at −103.0 ppm with the introduction of Zn and Pt is consistent with the IR results, indicating Pt and/or Zn species are trapped by the silanol nest of S-1 zeolite. To further clarify the detailed location of Zn species in S-1 zeolite, UV–vis analysis was conducted as shown in Fig. S14 . As a contrast, a strong ultraviolet absorption edge located at ∼ 370 nm is observed for commercial ZnO nanoparticles, which is ascribed to the charge transfer from O2– to Zn2+.[21,32] In the case of both modified 2.0Zn/S-1 and Zn@S-1 zeolites, no signal was detected at the wavelength of 370 nm, indicating that the introduced Zn species does not form ZnO crystalline domain on the S-1 surface or the highly dispersed ZnO clusters are below the detection limit. For 0.5Pt/2.0Zn/S-1 and 0.5Pt/Zn@S-1, the existence of a sharp band below 240 nm is generally corresponding to the Si-O-Zn structure.[21,32] Moreover, the order of absorption band intensity (ca. ∼ 205 nm) is 0.5Pt/Zn@S-1 > 0.5Pt/2.0Zn/S-1 > S-1, which may be associated with the formation of more Si-O-Zn structure. Thus, it can be inferred that Zn cations mainly exist in the 0.5Pt/Zn@S-1 catalyst. The regulated metal-support interaction can usually be reflected by the reducibility of metal species on zeolites and studied by H2-TPR. As shown in Fig. 6 , there is no visible reduction peak of the 0.5Pt/S-1. The formed Zn species of the two 2.0Zn/S-1 and Zn@S-1 samples from different synthesis methods caused distinct reduction peaks, which correspond to external oxidized Zn species. However, a weak signal of H2 consumption appears on 0.5Pt/Zn@S-1 and 0.5Pt/2.0Zn/S-1 catalysts, indicating that the introduction of Pt promoted the reduction of oxidized Zn species. Moreover, the reduction peak at ∼ 390 °C of 0.5Pt/Zn@S-1 catalyst is slightly lower than that of 0.5Pt/2.0Zn/S-1 catalyst (∼415 °C) ( Table S5 ), associated with their different particle sizes. In addition, the faint H2 consumption may correspond to a small proportion of surface ZnO engaged in the reduction process. Above FTIR, 29Si NMR, UV–Vis, and H2-TPR results show that in the 0.5Pt/Zn@S-1 catalyst, the confined Zn species are anchored by abundant silanol functional groups on the internal surface of S-1 zeolite, and are incorporated into the “defect sites” of zeolite to form framework Zn species. The post-impregnated Pt modulates the reduction properties of Zn, and the stable bimetallic structure can be constructed by harnessing the structural stability of framework Zn. 3.4 The surface reactivity of the 0.5Pt/Zn@S-1 catalyst The acidity of the prepared catalysts is studied by NH3-TPD. As shown in Fig. S15 , the S-1 and 0.5Pt/S-1 show no significant acidity. When Zn species was introduced into these catalysts, a big and broad peak centered at ∼ 200 °C is assigned to weak acidity.[57] The above results show that Zn species can modify the surface acidity property of pure-silica S-1 zeolite. Py-IR spectrum was also applied to further study the types of acidic sites. As presented in Fig. 7 , the primitive S-1 zeolite has no surface acid signal. The vibration bands at 1444 and 1597 cm−1 of 0.5Pt/S-1 are attributed to hydrogen (H)-bonded pyridine adsorption,[58,59] at the same time as indicates that Pt species will not cause acidity. As for 2.0Zn/S-1 and Zn@S-1 zeolites, the vibration bands at 1450 and 1540 cm−1 belonged to Lewis (L) and Brönsted (B) acid sites, respectively.[60,61] Combining with the semi-quantitative analysis for the amounts of L and B acid sites (Table 2 ), it shows that the Zn species mainly produces L acid sites, and the B/L ratio of 0.5Pt/Zn@S-1 catalyst is 0.015, which is lower than that of 0.111 for the 0.5Pt/2.0Zn/S-1 catalyst. Furthermore, the adsorption properties of the product over the catalysts were investigated by C3H6-TPD. Fig. S16 shows that the changes in propylene adsorption on the catalysts are kept in good line with the changes in the surface acidic property. To be specific, the desorption peak appears with the introduction of Zn. The peak centered at ∼ 200 °C indicates that propylene weakly interacts with the catalyst surface.[62] Hence, the altered nature of the catalyst surface for product adsorption is caused by the Zn species, and at the same time, the acidic sites generated by Zn species do not hamper the propylene selectivity. 3.5 Chemical state and coordination environment of atomically dispersed Pt active sites in the catalyst The detailed coordination structure of the catalytic active site of 0.5Pt/Zn@S-1 catalyst before and after the reaction was studied by X-ray absorption spectrum.[63] In the XANES spectra of the Pt L3 edge (Fig. 8 A), the height of the white line on the Pt L3-edge over the fresh 0.5Pt/Zn@S-1 catalyst is the same as that of the PtO2, but that of the spent catalyst is near to that of Pt foil. In other words, the oxidized Pt species are reduced to the metallic Pt0 active sites during the reaction condition, which follows the previous reports.[29,33] In the XANES spectra of Zn K-edge ( Fig. S17 A), the white line of the 0.5Pt/Zn@S-1 catalyst did not change significantly before and after the reaction. As shown in Fourier transformed EXAFS spectrum (Fig. 8 B), the peaks located at 1.60 Å and 2.64 Å are corresponded to PtO2 and Pt foil, while the peak of 2.25 Å located in between PtO2 and Pt foil attributed to Pt-Zn path. Moreover, the detailed coordination environment of the samples is further determined by the Fourier-transformed EXAFS of Pt L3-edge and Zn K-edge (Fig. 8 , Fig. S17 -18 and Table 3 , Table S6 ). The coordination numbers of Pt-O and Pt-Zn paths of the 0.5Pt/Zn@S-1 catalyst after the reaction (0.5Pt/Zn@S-1-U) are 1.4 ± 0.6 and 3.4 ± 1.3, respectively. The lack of a Pt-Pt path excludes the presence of Pt particles in a metallic state and suggests the atomically dispersed Pt1Znm bimetallic sites in the zeolite.[64–69] However, it is worth mentioning that the peak intensities of 0.5Pt/Zn@S-1 catalyst before and after the reaction in the EXAFS spectra (Fig. 8 B) are quite different, which may be because more Pt-O species are transformed into Pt-Zn structure during the reaction, consistentwith the observation in Pt L3-edge XANES spectrum. Compared with the pre-reduced 0.5Pt/S-1 sample existed the metallic Pt particles with the coordination number of 9.4 ± 1.5, the Pt-Pt bond is interrupted by the introduced Zn species of the pre-reduced 0.5Pt/2.0Zn/S-1, forming the Pt-Zn bond with the coordination number of 6.5 ± 2.0 ( Fig. S19 and Table S7 ). Therefore, the bimetallic nanoparticles of PtZn are formed after reduction treatment for 0.5Pt/2.0Zn/S-1 catalyst. Furthermore, the wavelet-transformed (WT) EXAFS spectrum is applied to examine the coordination environment more intuitively ( Fig. 9 and Fig. S20 ).[70] Three distinct different WT maxima of around 11.4 Å−1, 7.6 Å−1, and 9.0 Å−1 are attributed to the Pt-Pt, Pt-O, and Pt-Zn path, respectively. Combined with the EXAFS and (WT) EXAFS in Zn K-edge, only the primary first scattering shell of Zn-O is observed, indicating the Zn are mainly coordinated with O atoms in the catalyst. Considering the XAS is a bulk technique, it is deduced that only a little portion of Zn atoms are coordinated with Pt. In-situ DRIFTS-CO was also used to study the electronic structure of the Pt active site. The fresh 0.5Pt/S-1 catalyst shows a linear adsorption peak of CO located at 2068 cm−1, while the pre-reduced catalyst has an additional CO linear adsorption peak of 2046 cm−1, indicating two kinds of Pt atoms are co-existed as metallic nanoparticles in the spent 0.5Pt/S-1 (Fig. 10 A). Similarly, the two same peaks of 2068 cm−1 and 2047 cm−1 appeared in the 0.5Pt/Zn@S-1 catalyst after the pre-reduction, and there is an extra CO adsorption peak at around ∼ 1998 cm−1. Meanwhile, the absence of the signals appearing in the range of 2100–2200 cm−1 implies the trace amount of oxidized Pt species is below the detection limit of FTIR. Furthermore, noblue shiftphenomenonalso demonstrates that the valence state of Pt active sites remains metallic (i.e. Pt0 sites) of 0.5Pt/Zn@S-1 catalyst during the reduction process (Fig. 10 B). However, the 0.5Pt/2.0Zn/S-1 catalyst only shows a linear adsorption band of CO and accompanies with a red shift after pre-reduction (Fig. 10 C). In a nutshell, the role of Zn species plays a role in modulating the geometry and coordination environment of Pt sites, which is in line with XANES spectra. Furthermore, based on the CO pulse experiment ( Fig. S22 ), it can be seen that the Pt dispersions of monometallic 0.5Pt/S-1 and 0.5Pt/2.0Zn/S-1 catalysts are 10.7 % and 21.4 %, respectively. The 0.5Pt/Zn@S-1 catalyst has the highest Pt dispersion of 42.1 %. The relationship between the Pt sites and Zn species causes the Pt active site structure to be atom dispersed but not completely exposed on the surface in terms of quantity. This result demonstrates that the intimate relationship between Pt and Zn in 0.5Pt/2.0Zn/S-1 catalyst will lead to Zn species on the surface covering part of Pt sites. Interestingly, the Zn species on the surface of Zn@S-1 zeolite modified by confinement promote the dispersion of Pt sites and effectively improve the PDH performance of 0.5Pt/Zn@S-1 bimetallic catalyst. To sum up, the detailed coordination structure of atomically dispersed Pt1Zn3 sites is analyzed by the Fourier-transformed EXAFS and the wavelet-transformed EXAFS. Moreover, the XANES and DRIFTS-CO characterizations indicate that the positively charged atomically dispersed bimetallic Pt-Zn structure serves as active sites. As a result, the derived synergic effect between Pt and Zn species contributes to enhancing the PDH performance. 3.6 The investigation into the spent catalyst to unveil the origination of stability The morphology of the spent catalysts was also studied by TEM (Fig. 11 ). It can be seen that the 0.5Pt/Zn@S-1 catalyst is still consistent with the fresh counterpart, even though it suffered from 40 h of PDH reaction. Moreover, no metal particles can be observed in dark-field TEM images of the spent 0.5Pt/Zn@S-1 catalyst ( Fig. S23 ). As for the spent 0.5Pt/2.0Zn/S-1 catalyst, larger PtZn particles are unevenly distributed on the surface of the catalyst, which may be associated with fast deactivation. In contrast, the big bright spot in the dark field TEM images of 0.5Pt/2.0Zn/S-1 catalyst represents the agglomeration of metal particles ( Fig. S24 ). The result of dot scanning shows the compact interaction between Pt and Zn species. Furthermore, EDS and line scanning also show an apparent discrepancy in sintering resistance on these two catalysts. To further explore the coke resistance of catalysts, the spent catalysts were analyzed by TG accordingly, as presented in Fig. 12 . As can be seen from Fig. 12, the carbon deposition of 8.4 % over the 0.5Pt/2.0Zn/S-1 catalyst is more serious than that of 5.7 % over 0.5Pt/Zn@S-1 catalyst, elucidating that the encapsulated Zn species effectively improve coking resistance of 0.5Pt/Zn@S-1 catalyst. Moreover, the Raman spectrum has no stretching vibration signal of carbonaceous species ( Fig. S25 ), which demonstrates the low carbon deposition on the catalyst surface. 4 Conclusions In summary, modified Zn-zeolites synthesized by different strategies were used as substances to support Pt. The 0.5Pt/Zn@S-1 catalyst shows a propane (25 % C3H8 in Ar) dehydrogenation performance with ∼ 34.2 % propane conversion and ∼ 95.1 % propylene selectivity (propylene turnover rate of 14.2 s−1 under a WHSV of 94.2 h−1 of pure C3H8). Moreover, the optimal catalyst exhibits the catalytic stability of up to 60 h without distinct deactivation under a WHSV of 49.1 h−1, further indicating the robust structure of active sites for 0.5Pt/Zn@S-1. However, the deactivation in pure propane and regeneration in air under harsh conditions of the catalyst suggest it cannot be restored after 2nd regeneration due to aggregation of metals. As indicated by FT-IR, 29Si MAS NMR, and XAS spectrum, the dense silanol nests assist in obtaining the robustness of the confined Pt-Zn bimetallic structure, thus realizing the synergistic effect between Pt and Zn species. Compared with the 0.5Pt/2.0Zn/S-1 catalyst, the 0.5Pt/Zn@S-1 catalyst proves that confined Zn species are more beneficial to promote the Pt dispersion, and forming atomically dispersed Pt1Zn3 sites. This work provides an effective reference for designing highly dispersed precious metal-zeolite catalysts with superior catalytic performance. coredata.dc:description: The utilization of Pt-based catalysts in the catalytic conversion of propane to propylene (PDH) remains pivotal in industrial processes. However, the scarcity of Pt and its high cost necessitates innovative strategies to enhance Pt dispersion and catalytic performance. In this study, we present an approach involving the in-situ incorporation of Zn cations into Silicalite-1 (S-1) zeolite through one-pot hydrothermal synthesis, which facilitates the anchoring of atomically dispersed Pt atoms. The synthesized 0.5Pt/Zn@S-1 catalyst exhibits the dehydrogenation performance of 25 % propane for approximately 34.2 % propane conversion and 95.1 % propylene selectivity (propylene turnover rate of 14.2 s−1), coupled with robust stability of up to 60 h without distinct deactivation under a WHSV of 49.1 h−1. Comprehensive characterizations reveal the formation of atomically dispersed Pt-Zn catalytic sites. The Pt atoms are incorporated with the Zn cations and dense silanol nests. This unique configuration facilitates a synergistic effect between Pt and Zn for dehydrogenation.

coredata.dc:title: Zinc cations incorporated in Silicalite-1 zeolite assist in anchoring atomically dispersed platinum catalyst for boosted and robust propane dehydrogenation
